posts.content:
It shames me somewhat that I've never really used the Rogue class as a rogue. I've used it often to grab what I can from it while focusing more on other things - after all, it's a very handy class to bolt on. Anyway, I thought now was the time to pay it some more attention - hence this.

I've gone for a build with full capability to disarm, set and recover all epic traps (apart from plot-specific ones, of course), with a good measure of stealth and acceptable melee abilities (including 14d6 sneak attack damage).

Naturally, I have questions: what to take as my final 2 Rogue bonus feats? I opted for Skill Mastery and Slippery Mind, but could easily have gone for an Epic Skill Focus or 2, or a couple of  Improved Sneak Attacks, or Self-Concealments. A shrewd or dodgy decision? I also find myself with 51 skill points to distribute. A sizeable chunk will go on Open Lock, but I have no idea how many is good enough to open all locks bar plot-specific ones. The rest I'm looking to distribute between a permutation of Heal, Lore, and Persuade, though there may be better options. If I followed the guidance correctly (which ain't guaranteed), I think I've done what I can with the Search and trapping skills.

Anyway, do please have a look. Any feedback is welcome (I'd prefer it not to be over-rude, but hey, I'm sure I'll have had worse ).

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
When making a Rogue-focused build, I like to spread out the non-Rogue levels so that your skills don't fall too far behind.  For example, at level 7, this build will have the skills of a level 3 Rogue, and will have a hard time with traps and locks.  Furthermore, you will want to take Rogue at levels that end with 2 and 7 to get the AC from Tumble as soon as possible, and with CHA 8, you might also want Rogue at levels that end with 3 and 8 for the next multiple of 5 UMD.

I would take Two Weapon Fighting before Ambidexterity because TWF benefits all main-hand attacks, while Ambidexterity benefits only the off-hand attack, but then again, I wouldn't dual-wield until I have both anyway.

Since your Reflex saves are so good, I would swap Improved Evasion with Crippling Strike.

If your opponent has Blind Fight, your protection from concealment is squared because they get a second chance if their attack is blocked by your concealment, so 50% becomes 25%, 40% becomes 16%, 30% becomes 9%, 20% becomes 4%, and 10% becomes 1%.  Because of this, it is not worth taking Self Concealment unless you go all the way to SC 5.

For the skills, I would max Open Lock and put the left-over points into Lore.  Maybe take 4 points of Appraise at level 1 and never touch it again.

EDIT: I took so long to type this that it is no surprise that I was ninja'd.

Hi Stag
I think the updated draft is a strong build with 33 rogue levels that is a lot of sneak attack and a lot of skill points.
With 6 CoT levels I think you should try to get BAB 26 for that extra attack / round, without dual wielding it means an initial two hit flurry from stealth (ie HiPS) without Haste.
I would just choose either a melee weapon or ranged weapon as your focus, I think it is too difficult to focus on both without more fighter or CoT levels for bonus feats.
I think your goal of keeping Will above 20 is a noble one, and you can drop a great dexterity or two for Epic Will and maybe I would suggest epic fortitude too, as certain fortitude focused spells such as Implosion and Flesh to Stone there are no immunities to (ie death magic immunity does not protect against implosion) 
Fighter rather than CoT can be considered as an option, for an extra feat and easier leveling, you would lose some saves, Paladin is another option for extra saves (double buffable with CHA and the other stat), disease/fear immunity especially if decide not to dual wield and drop the ranged weapon weapon focus (which I think is a luxury).
I would change your weapon to shortsword mace or handaxe if you choose Fighter or Paladin for a little extra damage.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Well Empyre, I have not given that much of advice yet. But I have given him a challenge.

I do agree that a dual weapon focus is a step backwards.

Stag, in my opinion playing a rogue is to a large degree about having options and being able to control the field by planning ahead.
SA is powerful and should be honed. That means taking a lot of it, having a reasonable AB and have many attacks per round for max damage per flurry. IKD helps land SA in toe to toe combat. Stealth gives SA and adds to AB when flat footed and when flanking.
Stealth also gives tactical advatages.
HIPS adds an immense tactical improvement to stealth. In general HIPS is far more powerful than EWS.

I already hear you ask: But what about sneak immunes, and what about true seeing?
This is where you will need options, both tactical and by different means to do damage. Here skills come into play. A carpet of traps and UMD for items and spells are examples.
Traps and scrolls often work well against difficult warrior types too.

Rogue is also about defense with evasion, uncanny dodge, slippery mind, defensive roll, epic dodge and self concealment. UMD also adds here with protective spells cast from caster items or scrolls.

Rogues are also scouts, or commandos if you like, with hidden operations of gathring information and finding the best ways of initiating an attack.

Rogues gain entrance by opening locks and disarming traps and can be burglars and thieves.
They are masters of skills with most skills as class skills and the highest number if skill points per level.

You can build a rogue with focus on martial combat, armed or unarmed. He will be different from a pure warrior, but you can still play him as a warrior.
You don't need any advice on that. You already played the Halfling Champion and you know how to build a warrior.

It was not my intention to push this in the direction of mage. There are some good rogue/wizard builds, but UMD and scrolls will do for most rogues.

I hope this makes it more clear where I try to get with this.
Playing a rogue can be a unique and quite different way of handling both combat and other situations in game.
My advice is to try it out and see for yourself if you enjoy it.
When you know how to play a rogue, you will also know how to build one.

posts.author: Orion

Hey Stag
If I can add to Micks comments, when you do playtest a rogue, expect the first few levels to be very challenging solo, as one does not have a lot of sneak attack yet, no knockdown and skills are not fully developed and to get sneaks you will not want to tank without knockdown, HiPS or darkness/ultravision. It is best to use all the tools available to you- stealth, traps, UMD, picking off targets one by one, ranged weapons - to the maximum. Later on it gets much much easier. On the topic of UMD, early levels try out if you can, a wand of sleep on low will save enemies. You might enjoy that as a rogue :)

Thanks for the encouraging noises, both!

Right, Mr Black has departed this world (well, for a while anyway). Afraid I had to rely on a little naughtiness (let's call it resourcefulness, to be kind) to do it.

As is standard practice for me, I parked Criosa out of harm's way, then laid my first minefield just level with where the first wave of merc attacks takes place, having let the valiant guards go belting headlong into the fray (and their doom) as a distraction.

While they were off being hacked to ribbons and thinning the herd, I went trotting over to the emptier side of the screen (left side as you head down the screen), and put down a proper welcome mat. Then I went back and told Criosa to follow me, and made her stop behind this second field.

I then scuttled back and pulled those I could into the first minefield. This only left Robert, two of his mercs, and the sorcerer on the bridge. Back to just in front of the second field, where I waved a cheery "hello" to them, and they pursued (except that damned sorcerer). Once they were in the killing field, I activated Criosa while I went to play with Spelly McSpell Face. posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Fair enough Stag, I'll show you some cards.
After leaving the caves you come to a winter area before the area with the hill with the combat zone down to Culdeny.
I take the Princess with me and talk to the sargent on the hilltop. I let them all follow me back to the winter area outside the caves. I ask tham all to wait there out of harms way and enter the combat zone alone.

With a trapper, I have taken ranks in craft trap. Then I can craft electric- and fire average- or strong traps.
I pull the minions one by one over a trap (or two) with a ranged weapon, run off, go stealth and attack with a sneak attack.
The spies come under stealth, ofte when you have pulled another minion. One on one they don't do much damage unless they can SA you. Have high detect skills, so you see them come. Use the archer's belt you found earlier to avoid all damage.
When RB is alone, use a really thick carpet of low tier traps, or a carpet of average or strong traps. Pull him across and see his horse stumble and fall.
If his mage is still there, give him regular minion treatmemt.
Now go back to Criosa and have her follow you to town. Ask the soldiers too, if you like.
There are of course other ways to do this. RB is on horse and faster than the others. If you can slow him (tangle), you can run in circles around the whole force with your boots of travelling, bombarding them with fireballs from a necklace or wand. You can combine that with a field of traps...etc.
You can also send forward your cannon fodder and bombard the melee group with fireballs.
These are just some ideas. I am sure that others have different approaches to this battle.

If you have HIPS - you can have that by level 8- well that's another cup of tea.

RB is fast, so running only works if you can slow him down. I must admit that I have not used this method in this specific battle yet, but I would like to test it out. The challenge is how to target RB when surrounded by his forces. He is faster than his troops. That should make it possible to single him out.

Another tip if you recover traps. Some mods give xp when you disarm traps. For some reason you don't get that xp when you recover floor traps. You get the xp when you recover traps from doors and containers, though.
This is especially important if you play rogue based modules where a substantial part of xp come from the use of skills; eg: A Dance With Rogues.

posts.author: Stagmeister

Hello there, DarkShinobi - and thank you very much!

I know what you mean about those first few levels in Aielund: I remember the first time I went there I was KBR (killed by rats), which did not make me feel good. This time I went very much against the grain for me, and took it all as slowly as I could - scouting out areas in stealth and trying, where possible, to pull baddies one at a time. At the outset, traps were hard to come across or afford, so I had to rely on my sling and those little things you can grab from the sage, such as tanglefoot bags. I also tried to prioritise getting the quests done - I could always go back later and mop up the screen - for maximum xp, and so faster advancement. I think my biggest investment in gear was a pair of Boots of Travelling, when I could afford it: they gave me a bit of an edge in getting away from horrid surprises. This was also the first time I made use of the catapult against the big wyvern. Essentially, it's all about getting to know your build, playing to its strengths and attempting to minimize opportunities for others to take advantage of its weaknesses.

Being honest, I would have loved Dante and Nell along with me, but that wasn't part of Mick's challenge. I'd also have loved a level of Shadowdancer for HiPS, and maybe some Monk because, frankly, I love me some Monk. But that's a thought for me to explore another day...

Seeing your name, and with you saying you'd be going elf, one build popped straight into my mind. It's by Mick and contains no Rogue at all (perversely), but it is great. It's his Kama Shinobi

Hope this helps a bit!

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister

Quick update for those who may be interested (apologies to the rest of you).

Just finished the second part of Aielund with Sturm und Drang, but no soloing this time. I'd have liked Ronan, but he's also a Rogue, so no real point. I ended up doing the girls on tour - me, Valennia, and Maggie. Maggie (our Hin Druid) remains superb, and Valennia, while a proper Barbarian lass, does take some management.

By and large it was a breeze, with the only real problems coming on the Isle of the Dead and in the final confrontation in the throne room. The first was down to those respawning Abyssal Spectres - Val running off before I could stop her (I give these people too much rope) and me unable to lay sufficient minefields. I ended up taking the quickest route to the dead dragon (picking up loot from poor deceased you-know-who). The dragon itself, and indeed the lich, were a walk in the park. The main problem with the throne room battle, was that it starts immediately after the cutscene, which gives you no time to prepare your killing field(s), so a lot of sneaking took place. Maggie and I concentrated on the Cleric, while Val took on the katana WM. Once we'd got rid of Chen (the Cleric) it was relatively simple - though Val did peg out. I brought her back before we went to rescue Criosa. Again. And great was the joy.

One little tip as a trapsmith. That screen you go to to track the hunter who's been killing folk is an absolute godsend. There are a good thirty-forty traps to be recovered in that area - makes blowing up shadow druids much easier!

The build still cries out for HiPS and either Monk or Assassin, but hey, what can you do?

Tbc, if I, and you, can be arsed.

Cheers

EDIT: Should have mentioned, I dropped Slippery Mind for Crippling Strike, and it really is your friend.
